task_description: Given a pair of news headlines, predict which one gets more clicks by user. Note that the headlines are about the same news and only differs in their linguistic styles.

values: Headline 1 has more clicks than Headline 2
Headline 2 has more clicks than Headline 1
label.description: Label of which headline ended up getting more clicks

known_hypotheses: Headlines that evoke negative emotions or emotional intensity are more likely to attract clicks, while positive emotions have less impact.
Longer and more complex headlines tend to perform better, providing context and engaging readers through cognitive effort.
Concrete language that evokes vivid imagery and sensory cues enhances engagement, comprehension, and recall.
Surprising or unexpected phrasing, including cliffhangers, increases curiosity and encourages clicks.
Headlines mentioning prominent figures, trending topics, or social proof (e.g., popularity metrics) attract more attention.
Using numbers in headlines (e.g., '5 Ways to...') boosts engagement by implying structured and digestible content.
Unique and distinctive phrasing, especially when different from recent similar headlines, tends to perform better.
Headlines that pose intriguing questions or suggest an information gap prompt readers to click for answers.
Incorporating action-oriented language with verbs and adverbs makes headlines more dynamic and engaging.
Clear and unambiguous headlines perform well, but some complexity or disfluency can also boost engagement by intriguing readers.
